study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-pressure (HP), freeze-thaw cycles (FTC), and germination-parboiling (GP) treatments on lipid digestibility and rancidity in brown rice.
results_summary: GP-treated brown rice released the most fatty acids during digestion, while FTC-treated rice had the highest fat acidity during storage. HP and GP treatments improved lipid oxidation stability, whereas FTC-treated rice required anaerobic storage to prevent rancidity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the texture and sensory quality of brown rice by studying the effects of defatting and hydrothermal treatment, either alone or combined, on cooking quality and microscopic morphology.
results_summary: Defatting combined with hydrothermal treatment significantly improved brown rice quality, reducing hardness and chewiness while increasing sensory scores, water absorption, and cooking efficiency. Microscopic analysis revealed increased cracks and micropores, likely contributing to these improvements.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general consumer acceptability focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how germination and fortification affect the functionality and digestibility of brown rice by altering its starch structure.
results_summary: Germination and fortification reduced amylose content, crystallinity, and short-range order of starch, leading to lower peak viscosity, enthalpy change, and starch hydrolysis rate. The effects became more pronounced with longer germination times, with fortified brown rice showing the lowest viscosity and enthalpy after 34 hours of germination.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal model given the focus on starch structure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the presence of toxic heavy metals in Brown Hassawi rice and evaluate the effectiveness of cooking methods in reducing these contaminants.
results_summary: The study found that Brown Hassawi rice samples exceeded maximum allowable limits for As and Pb, with Cd nearly reaching the limit in some samples. Cooking with high water ratios was more effective in reducing metal content, except for Cd, but estimated daily intake of As remained above safe levels.
population_specificity: Residents of the Al-Ahsa region in Saudi Arabia consuming Brown Hassawi rice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) content and sensory characteristics of brown rice cake using static magnetic field (SMF)-assisted germination.
results_summary: SMF significantly increased GABA content in germinated brown rice (GBR) and GBR cake, improved texture, flavor, and storage stability by altering starch, protein, and fiber hydrolysis.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on brown rice samples).
effective_dosage: 60% GBR, 40% white rice, 1% yeast, 20% sugar, 55% water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if low protein fermented genmai (brown rice) could improve chronic kidney disease management by retaining functional features of brown rice while reducing protein and harmful mineral content.
results_summary: The study found that replacing staple foods with LPFG reduced protein intake, improved gut microbiota, decreased urinary protein excretion, and enhanced kidney function without side dish restrictions. Preliminary results showed reduced constipation and improved glomerular and tubular function after 3 months.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (staple food replacement without side dish restriction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ultrasonication treatment on the germination rate of brown rice and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment increased the germination rate of brown rice by up to 28% at 30 hours, linked to increased concentrations of low-molecular metabolites, transcription factors, and enhanced carbon metabolism. Multi-omics analysis identified 867 differentially expressed genes and 498 differentially accumulated metabolites associated with germination.
population_specificity: Brown rice grains
effective_dosage: Ultrasound treatment at 40 kHz for 30 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the health-promoting properties of fermented rice bran extracts from black rice (H7F) and germinated brown rice (G13F), focusing on prebiotic effects, antipathogenic activity, and safety.
results_summary: The study found that H7F and G13F extracts promoted the growth of beneficial bacteria (Lactobacillus delbrueckii subsp. lactis), exhibited antipathogenic activity against E. coli and S. aureus, and significantly reduced blood cholesterol levels without toxicity in Wistar rats.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (in vivo study) and in vitro bacterial models.
effective_dosage: 25 mg/mL (MIC) and 50 mg/mL (MBC) for antipathogenic activity; dosage for in vivo study not specified.
study_duration: Acute and chronic toxicity studies conducted, but exact duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether replacing refined white rice with germinated brown rice (GBR) could improve metabolic outcomes in type 2 diabetes patients and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: GBR significantly reduced fasting blood glucose (62% effective rate) and increased beneficial gut bacteria and short-chain fatty acids, while decreasing harmful bacteria and inflammatory markers. It also improved intestinal homeostasis and immune cell balance.
population_specificity: 99 type 2 diabetes patients (average age 64.58 ± 5.06 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of zinc sulfate fortification and germination on increasing zinc content and bioavailability in brown rice.
results_summary: Zinc content and bioavailability in brown rice increased with zinc sulfate concentration (0-100 mg/L) and germination time (10-34 h), with optimal results at 25 mg/L and 28 h. Germination also improved total phenol content, antioxidant activity, and reduced phytic acid, while zinc fortification did not significantly alter crystalline structure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or plant-based study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of heat-moisture treated brown rice crackers (HMT-BR-C) on endothelial function, specifically postprandial flow-mediated dilation (FMD), compared to regular brown rice crackers (BR-C) and white rice crackers (WR-C).
results_summary: HMT-BR-C intake significantly increased postprandial FMD response compared to baseline, while BR-C and WR-C showed no significant change. The increase in FMD was associated with higher levels of free and bound ferulic acids in HMT-BR-C, though no differences were found in postprandial glucose levels or total polyphenol content.
population_specificity: 12 adults with mild endothelial dysfunction (FMD < 7.0%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of pre-germinated brown rice (PGBR) on high fructose and high fat-induced non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and cardiac complications in rodents.
results_summary: PGBR significantly reduced body, hepatic, and cardiac weight gains, improved lipid homeostasis, and inhibited inflammation in rodents fed a high-fructose and high-fat diet. It also lowered elevated blood pressure, heart rate, liver function indices, and inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: WKY rats (rodents)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fermented brown rice beverage (BA) could beneficially alter gut microbiota composition in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS) compared to fermented white rice beverage (WA).
results_summary: The study found that BA significantly increased beneficial gut bacteria (e.g., Clostridia class species) and short-chain fatty acid production compared to WA, suggesting a positive modulation of gut microbiota in MetS patients.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome (n = 40).
effective_dosage: Daily fermented brown rice beverage (BA) or fermented white rice beverage (WA) as a meal replacement (exact volume not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a specific blend of biofunctional boiled rice (WFBSK) could prevent type 2 diabetes and dementia by improving cognitive function and reducing insulin secretion.
results_summary: Consumers of WFBSK rice showed significant improvement in language memory and lower insulin secretion levels compared to those who consumed control white rice. The rice blend was rich in beneficial compounds like dietary fiber, anthocyanin, and free ferulic acid.
population_specificity: 24 subjects (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Blending ratio of 4:4:2 (SHBR:WFBBR:KBR) with 2.5% WBB and 0.3% rice oil after high-pressure treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pulsed light (PL) on germination and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) production in brown rice, as well as the correlations among glutamic acid (Glu) content, glutamate decarboxylase (GAD) activity, and GABA content.
results_summary: PL exposure increased germination and GABA content in brown rice, with earlier peaks in Glu (18h) and GABA (24h) compared to the control. PL also enhanced GAD activity and free amino acid content early in germination, showing GABA production is regulated by GAD activity and positively correlated with Glu content.
population_specificity: Brown rice (germinating grains)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combined remediation strategy (FeCl3 washing and biochar treatment) could effectively reduce cadmium (Cd) contamination in paddy soil and subsequently lower Cd accumulation in brown rice.
results_summary: The study found that the combined treatment removed 30.9% of total Cd and 41.6% of bioavailable Cd from soil, reduced Cd content in brown rice by 45.5-62.5%, and increased rice yield by 2.7-11.8%. The Cd levels in brown rice fell below China's national safety standard.
population_specificity: Paddy soil and brown rice cultivars (Zhuliangyou189 and Zhuliangyou929).
effective_dosage: 0.03 M FeCl3 at a liquid/soil ratio of 1.5:1, followed by 1% biochar.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how germination treatment affects the molecular and supramolecular structures and pasting behaviors of starches in native and germinated waxy brown rice.
results_summary: Germination increased α- and β-amylase activities, degraded starch chains, and reduced structural properties (double helices, crystallinity, lamellar ordering), leading to lower viscosity. These changes suggest improved processing suitability for germinated rice-based products.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on rice starch)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a brown rice diet could improve cognitive function in individuals aged over 60 years.
results_summary: The study examined cognitive function before and after a 6-month intervention with brown or white rice, but the abstract does not specify the results of the cognitive function measurements.
population_specificity: Individuals aged ≥60 years using elderly care facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of static magnetic field (SMF) treatment on germinated brown rice (GBR), focusing on α-amylase activity, starch properties, and germination metrics.
results_summary: SMF treatment improved α-amylase activity (15.2%), increased germination rate (9.7%-158.8%), and enhanced shoot/root growth and fresh weight. It also altered starch microstructure, reduced peak viscosity, but did not significantly affect crystalline type.
population_specificity: Brown rice (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: SMF exposure (10 mT, 60 min, 25°C) followed by germination (0-72 h, 30°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize ultrasound conditions for cellulase to improve its hydrolysis effect on rice bran and enhance the textural attributes of brown rice.
results_summary: Ultrasonication at 1.67 W cm-3 for 30 min significantly improved cellulase activity and efficiency, but pre-sonicated brown rice showed higher hydrolysis capacity with ultrasonicated cellulase. Ultrasound-assisted cellulase treatment improved edible quality but produced less glucose compared to successive ultrasound stimulation.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or lab-based study on brown rice samples).
effective_dosage: Ultrasonication at 1.67 W cm-3 for 30 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combined amendment could reduce cadmium (Cd) and arsenic (As) uptake in brown rice while improving soil health and rice quality in contaminated paddy soils.
results_summary: The combined amendment significantly reduced Cd and inorganic As concentrations in brown rice (up to 55.8% and 50.0%, respectively) and increased essential amino acids (up to 20.4%). Soil health indicators and root system metrics also improved.
population_specificity: Moderately and highly Cd- and As-co-contaminated paddy fields.
effective_dosage: 0, 450, and 900 g m-2 of the combined amendment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare metabolic and volatile compound profiles between Japonica and Indica rice cultivars after germination to identify potential health benefits.
results_summary: Japonica rice cultivars showed higher levels of health-promoting compounds like essential amino acids and GABA compared to Indica cultivars, while volatile organic compounds significantly decreased after germination. The study suggests Japonica cultivars may be preferable for health-focused GBR products.
population_specificity: Japonica and Indica rice cultivars (specific human population not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of replacing 50% of corn with brown rice (Japonica) in the diet of weanling pigs on growth performance, nutrient digestibility, and blood parameters.
results_summary: Pigs fed the brown rice diet showed higher final body weight, average daily gain, and digestibility of dry matter and energy compared to the control group, with no negative effects on feed intake, diarrhea frequency, or blood parameters.
population_specificity: 60 weanling pigs (28-day-old, 30 barrows and 30 gilts, 6.73 ± 0.77 kg body weight).
effective_dosage: 50% replacement of corn with brown rice in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether substituting brown rice as a staple food improves anthropometric parameters and blood glucose control in overweight women with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Brown rice intervention significantly reduced body weight, BMI, body fat percentage, abdominal circumference, fasting blood glucose, 2-h postprandial blood glucose, and HbA1c. Increased fiber intake correlated with decreased BMI and abdominal circumference, while magnesium intake showed a negative correlation with BMI changes.
population_specificity: Overweight women older than 40 years with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Three main meals and three snacks six days a week (specific brown rice quantity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of replacing corn with ground brown rice on growth performance, immune status, and gut microbiota in weanling pigs.
results_summary: Substituting corn with ground brown rice did not affect growth performance or diarrhea frequency but modulated immune status and gut microbiota by increasing beneficial microbial communities (e.g., Firmicutes, Lactobacillus, Streptococcus) and reducing harmful ones (e.g., Bacteroidetes, Clostridium, Prevotella).
population_specificity: Weanling pigs (28 days old, 6.78 ± 0.94 kg body weight).
effective_dosage: 100% replacement of corn with ground brown rice in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dielectric barrier discharge cold plasma (DBD-CP) treatment in preserving brown rice by analyzing physicochemical properties and flavor stability during storage.
results_summary: DBD-CP treatment reduced free fatty acid levels by 25.2%, improved color stability, and altered volatile organic components, with hexanal reduction serving as a treatment indicator. Flavor fingerprints of treated brown rice were distinguishable using headspace gas chromatography ion mobility spectrometry.
population_specificity: Brown rice samples (no human subjects specified).
study_duration: Storage period duration not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which salicylic acid (SA) spray reduces cadmium (Cd) accumulation in rice grains grown in Cd-contaminated soil.
results_summary: SA treatment reduced Cd accumulation in rice grains by decreasing Cd content in leaves at the flowering stage, modulating Cd transporters, and enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity without altering soil Cd levels.
population_specificity: Rice plants grown in Cd-contaminated soil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how sulfur application prior to wheat cultivation affects cadmium uptake in brown rice grown in low- and high-cadmium soils.
results_summary: Increasing sulfur levels initially raised cadmium accumulation in brown rice, peaking at 60 mg S kg-1, but decreased at 120 mg S kg-1 due to reduced cadmium solubility and inhibited uptake. Sulfur application increased cadmium accumulation risk in brown rice, making it unsuitable for Cd-contaminated soils.
population_specificity: Rice plants grown in controlled pot experiments with varying sulfur and cadmium levels.
effective_dosage: 0, 30, 60, 120 mg S kg-1 applied to wheat prior to rice cultivation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how sulfur application prior to oilseed rape cultivation affects cadmium uptake in brown rice grown in low- and high-cadmium soils.
results_summary: Sulfur application reduced cadmium solubility in low-Cd soils, decreasing brown rice Cd concentrations by up to 55%, but increased Cd uptake by up to 40% in high-Cd soils. The effects were linked to S-induced changes in soil pH, sulfide formation, and Cd-induced oxidative stress in rice plants.
population_specificity: Rice plants grown in controlled pot experiments with varying sulfur and cadmium levels.
effective_dosage: Sulfur applied at 0, 30, 60, and 120 mg S kg-1 soil; cadmium levels at 0.35 (low) and 10.35 (high) mg Cd kg-1 soil.
study_duration: Duration of rice growth to maturity (specific timeframe not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether eating glutinous brown rice (GBR) could improve glucose metabolism in subjects without diabetes.
results_summary: After 6 weeks, the GBR group showed a significant increase in serum 1,5-anhydroglucitol (1,5-AG), suggesting improved glucose metabolism. Body mass index decreased in both groups, but no significant changes were observed in fasting plasma glucose, fasting insulin, or eating behavior.
population_specificity: Japanese subjects without diabetes receiving annual medical checkups.
effective_dosage: GBR twice a day (specific amount not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of ultra-high hydrostatic pressure (UHHP)-processed brown rice (BR) on nutrient modification and its potential benefits for conditions like hyperlipidemia, diabetes, hypertension, osteoporosis, and brain cognition.
results_summary: UHHP-treated BR showed improved physicochemical and functional qualities, making it more palatable and nutritious than white rice or untreated BR. The study highlighted its potential benefits in managing metabolic diseases and age-related degenerative conditions.
population_specificity: Elderly population (focus on osteoporosis and brain cognition), as well as general models for hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of replacing corn with brown rice on growth performance, nutrient digestibility, carcass characteristics, and gut microbiota in growing and finishing pigs.
results_summary: The study found no differences in growth performance, nutrient digestibility, or carcass characteristics between pigs fed corn-based diets and those fed diets with up to 100% brown rice replacement. However, gut microbiota differences emerged during the finishing phase, suggesting long-term dietary effects.
population_specificity: Growing and finishing pigs (23.80 ± 2.96 kg BW; 10 weeks of age).
effective_dosage: 50%, 75%, and 100% replacement of corn with ground brown rice.
study_duration: 6 weeks per trial phase (growing and finishing periods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardioprotective effects of germinated brown rice (GBR) on chronic myocardial infarction in a rabbit model.
results_summary: GBR consumption significantly improved cardiac function, reduced heart rate, mean arterial pressure, and plasma glucose levels, and prevented life-threatening ventricular tachycardia and myocardial ischemia signs in rabbits.
population_specificity: New Zealand white rabbits with induced chronic myocardial infarction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of autoclaving on the nutritional, sensory, and health-promoting properties of germinated brown rice (GBR) in metabolic syndrome patients.
results_summary: Autoclaving improved taste and aroma, increased GABA and ferulic acid levels, and significantly reduced fasting and postprandial glucose, triglycerides, and cholesterol in metabolic syndrome patients.
population_specificity: Metabolic syndrome (MS) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cooked pre-germinated brown rice (PGBR) could effectively treat Metabolic Syndrome (MetS) by improving HDL cholesterol levels and reducing MetS prevalence.
results_summary: The study found that PGBR significantly reduced the percentage of patients with MetS and increased serum HDL cholesterol levels compared to the placebo group. These effects were statistically significant (p < 0.05).
population_specificity: 80 Vietnamese subjects (65.1 ± 3.81 years old) with Metabolic Syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antidiabetic and cytotoxic effects of modified germinated brown rice flour (MGBRF) treated with varying concentrations of CGTase.
results_summary: The study found that MGBRF modified with 598.38 U/ml of CGTase increased slowly digestible starch (55.8%) and resistant starch (5.92%), along with elevated levels of GABA and ferulic acid. The extract showed strong cytotoxic activity against HepG2 cells and stabilized glycemic index in diabetic mice.
population_specificity: Type 2-diabetic mice and HepG2 cancer cells.
effective_dosage: 0, 299.19, 598.38, and 897.57 U/ml of CGTase for 1 hour.
study_duration: Not specified for in vivo study; 1-hour modification for in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the metabolizable energy, amino acid digestibility, and effects of dietary brown rice supplementation on laying performance and egg quality in hens.
results_summary: Brown rice had high metabolizable energy (3,773 kcal/kg DM) and variable amino acid digestibility (32.7-96.6%). Up to 15% dietary inclusion showed no adverse effects on laying performance or egg quality.
population_specificity: Hy-line Brown laying hens (49-week-old in Exp. 1, 44-week-old in Exp. 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability and antioxidant activity of Se-MPS, a selenopeptide derived from brown rice, under various processing conditions.
results_summary: Se-MPS demonstrated superior stability and antioxidant activity compared to GSH and MPS, retaining most of its Cr(VI) reduction activity under different conditions, though it had negligible ABTS+ scavenging capacity. It showed potential as a candidate for nutraceuticals or functional food.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the preventive effect and mechanism of probiotic-fermented germinated brown rice (FGBR) on colorectal carcinogenesis in rats.
results_summary: FGBR reduced preneoplastic lesions, lowered inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β), and modulated apoptotic markers (increased Bax and cleaved caspase-3, decreased Bcl-2), suggesting potential chemopreventive effects against colorectal cancer.
population_specificity: Rats induced with colorectal carcinogenesis using DMH/DSS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antiproliferative, apoptotic, and antioxidative properties of ethanolic extracts from Cordyceps militaris-fermented rice (FRE) and fruiting bodies in human breast cancer cell lines.
results_summary: FRE from the Zhangzhou strain (FRE-Z) showed high cordycepin levels, strong antioxidant activity, and dose-dependent inhibition of breast cancer cell proliferation, linked to early apoptosis induction and p53 activation. FRE-Z also transiently increased cellular antioxidant enzyme activity in MCF-7 cells.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cholesterol-lowering and antioxidative effects of pregerminated brown rice (GBR) versus polished white rice (WR) in hypercholesterolemic rats.
results_summary: GBR showed higher levels of antioxidative phytochemicals, stronger in vitro free radical scavenging, and antihemolytic effects compared to WR. In hypercholesterolemic rats, GBR significantly reduced plasma and hepatic cholesterol, LDL-C, TG, and inflammatory markers while increasing HDL-C and fecal cholesterol excretion.
population_specificity: Experimentally-induced hypercholesterolemic rats (1% cholesterol diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the nutritional benefits of brown rice and advocate for its inclusion in rice breeding programs to address nutritional gaps caused by milling.
results_summary: Brown rice contains higher dietary fiber, proteins, unsaturated lipids, micronutrients, and bioactive compounds compared to milled rice. Some brown rice varieties have low glycemic index properties and high levels of bioactive compounds, which may help counter type II diabetes and improve overall nutrition.
population_specificity: General population, with potential relevance for individuals with type II diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of whole grain extrudate (97% brown rice and 3% defatted rice bran) on glucose metabolism and the hepatic insulin signaling pathway in diabetic mice.
results_summary: BRD treatment significantly reduced blood glucose, improved glucose intolerance and insulin resistance, increased hepatic glycogen content, and activated the IRS1/PI3K/AKT signaling pathway, indicating antidiabetic potential.
population_specificity: C57BL/KsJ-db/db mice (a model for diabetes mellitus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term dietary intake of ultra-high hydrostatic pressurized brown rice (UHHPBR) could prevent aging-related decline in bone mineral density in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that after 12 months, the UHHPBR group had significantly higher bone mineral density compared to the white rice group, with no reported adverse side effects. The results suggest UHHPBR may help attenuate osteoporosis in the elderly.
population_specificity: Elderly Japanese individuals (n=40; mean age 73.1 years) from Iinan-cho, Shimane, Japan.
effective_dosage: 100 g of UHHPBR and 100 g of white rice per day for the UHHPBR group; 200 g of white rice per day for the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how alternate wetting and drying (AWD) irrigation affects arsenic (As) migration from soil to brown rice compared to continuous flooding (CF).
results_summary: AWD irrigation significantly reduced arsenic content in brown rice (43.3%-85.0% lower than CF) by decreasing arsenic availability in rhizosphere soil and promoting arsenic sequestration by iron plaques on root surfaces. The dissolution factor (DF) of arsenic in porewater correlated positively with arsenic levels in brown rice, further supporting AWD's efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on soil-rice plant system dynamics).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and validate quantitative trait loci (QTLs) associated with low cadmium (Cd) accumulation in brown rice to improve safety and phytoremediation potential.
results_summary: The study identified four QTLs, including two novel ones (qBRCdC-9 and qBRCdC-12), that effectively reduced Cd concentration in brown rice across different genetic backgrounds. The QTL qBRCdC-12 was linked to low Cd translocation from shoot to brown rice, and six candidate genes were found to be upregulated in response to Cd treatment.
population_specificity: Rice cultivars (YaHui2816 and F2 populations derived from crosses with C268A, Lu98A, and 5406A).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) coupled with machine learning for the designation of origin (PDO) certification of Argentine brown rice.
results_summary: The study found that LIBS combined with XGBoost and k-NN algorithms achieved 84% accuracy, 100% sensitivity, and 78% specificity in classifying rice samples by PDO. The method was described as simple, clean, and easily applicable for rice certification.
population_specificity: Argentine brown rice samples from two PDOs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in bioactive phytochemicals between germinated brown rice (GBR) and cold plasma-treated GBR (PGBR) across six Thai rice cultivars.
results_summary: Cold plasma treatment improved germination rates, root length, and seedling height in the most sensitive cultivar. PGBR showed higher γ-oryzanol content and accelerated peak levels of certain phytochemicals compared to GBR, while antioxidant activity remained similar.
population_specificity: Six cultivars of Thai germinated brown rice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether germinated brown rice (GBR) combined with probiotics could inhibit colorectal carcinogenesis in rats and explore the potential mechanisms involved.
results_summary: GBR alone or combined with probiotics inhibited preneoplastic lesions, enhanced antioxidative capacity, and promoted apoptosis in the colon. The combination of GBR and probiotics showed synergistic effects in reducing carcinogenic markers and improving apoptotic protein expression.
population_specificity: Rats treated with DMH and DSS to induce colorectal carcinogenesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different processing methods (germination, exogenous enzyme treatment, and their combination) affect the fluidity, solubility, nutrient composition, digestibility, color, and aroma of instant brown rice powder.
results_summary: Different processing methods significantly influenced most properties of instant brown rice flour, except flavonoids. Germination reduced fluidity, solubility, and protein/starch digestibility, while exogenous enzyme treatment improved these factors. The combination of germination and enzymes increased starch digestibility but worsened fluidity and dispersion time. DBRE (likely a specific processing method) produced higher-quality powder than DGBRE.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or lab-based analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hydrothermal stability of phenolic extracts from brown rice and their impact on antioxidant activity.
results_summary: Hydrothermal treatment increased ferulic acid, p-coumaric acid, and free glucose while decreasing phenolic glycosides. Total phenolic and flavonoid content initially decreased by 5.7%-9.2% and 3.5%-5.8% but slightly recovered after 120 minutes, with only a minor reduction (<10%) in total antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on brown rice extracts)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a new deltamethrin formulation in protecting brown rice from infestation by Rhyzopertha dominica and Sitotroga cerealella over 12 months of storage.
results_summary: The new deltamethrin formulation significantly reduced progeny production of R. dominica (from 177.4 to 9.8 F₁ adults) and moderately reduced S. cerealella progeny (from 105.6 to 69.4 F₁ adults). Weight loss and feeding damage correlated with progeny production, showing the formulation's effectiveness, though S. cerealella was less susceptible.
population_specificity: Brown rice infested with Rhyzopertha dominica and Sitotroga cerealella.
effective_dosage: 0.5 and 1.0 ppm of deltamethrin emulsifiable concentrate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of heat-moisture treatment (HMT) of brown rice flour on the quality and digestibility of Korean rice cake (jeolpyeon).
results_summary: HMT of brown rice flour reduced lightness and increased redness/yellowness in rice cakes, lowered hardness/springiness/cohesiveness, increased resistant starch, and decreased rapidly digestible starch. Sensory evaluation showed lower hardness but also lower overall acceptability compared to untreated brown or white rice cakes.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on food product properties, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Brown rice flour with 20% moisture content, treated at 100-110°C for 1-2h.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre-germinated brown rice (PGBR) could reverse the adverse effects of dextromethorphan (DXM)-induced addiction on sperm quality, testicular structure, and androgen receptor expression in rats.
results_summary: PGBR treatment restored sperm motility and concentration to normal levels, normalized testicular structure, and recovered androgen receptor expression in Sertoli and Leydig cells after 60 days of administration in DXM-addicted rats. The study concluded that PGBR may be a novel therapeutic strategy for treating drug addiction-related reproductive dysfunction.
population_specificity: Male rats with DXM-induced addiction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of five fungicides in managing sheath blight disease in rice and assess their post-harvest residues in brown rice and other matrices.
results_summary: Thifluzamide 23.9% SC was the most effective in inhibiting Rhizoctonia solani, while azoxystrobin 18.2% + difenoconazole 11.4% SC performed best in field trials for disease reduction and yield enhancement. Post-harvest fungicide residues were below detectable limits, indicating safety for consumption and environmental use.
population_specificity: Rice crops affected by sheath blight disease (Rhizoctonia solani Kuhn AG-1 IA).
effective_dosage: Single/recommended doses (e.g., 1 ml/l for pencycuron 22.9% SC and azoxystrobin 18.2% + difenoconazole 11.4% SC) and double doses were tested.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a novel method for producing germinated brown rice (GBR) and assess its impact on GABA content, cooking, and taste qualities.
results_summary: The study found that cyclic cellulase conditioning and germination treatment maximized GABA accumulation without significantly affecting cooking or taste qualities. The treatment improved cooking and taste qualities by degrading crude fiber and increasing water absorption rate.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or food science context)
effective_dosage: 50 mg/ml cellulase solution treatment for 90 min followed by 32 h germination at 30°C

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-pressure-treated brown rice (HPBR) could improve cognitive dysfunction and reduce amyloid-β levels in an Alzheimer's disease mouse model.
results_summary: HPBR increased water absorbency without nutrient loss, ameliorated cognitive dysfunction, and reduced amyloid-β levels in the brain of the AD mouse model.
population_specificity: Senescence-accelerated mouse prone 8 (AD mouse model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vibigaba (germinated brown rice) contributes to weight loss in the context of an energy-restricted diet.
results_summary: The study identified methodological limitations and insufficient information for a complete evaluation. No conclusions could be drawn regarding Vibigaba's effect on weight loss.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability, tolerability, and feasibility of substituting brown rice for white rice to lower the risk of type 2 diabetes in a Nigerian population.
results_summary: Most participants preferred 100% brown rice after tasting, and higher proportions of brown rice in meals resulted in lower 2-hour postprandial glucose levels. Factors affecting acceptability included appearance, cooking time, cost, availability, and nutritional awareness.
population_specificity: 51 adults (19-60 years) in Abuja, Nigeria, stratified by age and BMI (normal weight vs. overweight/obese).
effective_dosage: Meals with varying brown rice proportions (25%, 50%, 75%, 100%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Phellinuslinteus on germinated brown rice (PBR) extracts could increase the sensitivity of KRAS-mutated colon cancer cells to cetuximab.
results_summary: The study found that PBR extract combined with cetuximab suppressed SW480 cell viability/proliferation, increased apoptosis, and reduced KRAS protein expression. In a tumor-xenografted mouse model, PBR and cetuximab co-treatment significantly suppressed tumor growth.
population_specificity: KRAS-mutated colon cancer cells (SW480) and tumor-xenografted mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vibigaba (germinated brown rice) contributes to maintaining normal blood cholesterol concentrations.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to support the claim, citing methodological limitations and lack of comprehensive literature review. No conclusions could be drawn regarding Vibigaba's effect on cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of heat-moisture treatment (HMT) on the chemical components, physical properties, and enzyme activities of two types of brown rice flour.
results_summary: HMT reduced α-amylase and lipase activities and fat acidity while slightly increasing dietary fiber and resistant starch levels. Treated rice samples showed lower fat acidity after storage, suggesting improved long-term storage stability, and HMT inhibited retrogradation, enhancing rice product quality.
population_specificity: Two types of brown rice flour (high-amylose Koshinokaori and normal-quality Koshiibuki).
effective_dosage: Five HMT conditions (0.1 MPa/120 °C for 5 or 10 min, 0.2 MPa/134 °C for 5 or 10 min, and 0.3 MPa/144 °C for 10 min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vibigaba (germinated brown rice) contributes to maintaining long-term normal blood glucose concentration.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to support the claim that Vibigaba maintains normal blood glucose levels due to methodological limitations and lack of comprehensive literature review. No conclusions could be drawn from the single human intervention study provided.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a fiber-rich diet with brown rice improves endothelial function in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The brown rice diet significantly improved endothelial function and subtly reduced glucose excursions compared to the white rice diet, without changes in HbA1c levels. High-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels also showed a trend toward improvement in the brown rice group.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus at a single general hospital in Japan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intervention with brown rice vs. white rice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dewaxed brown rice could improve constipation and body weight loss caused by long-term antibiotic administration in mice.
results_summary: Dewaxed brown rice significantly improved constipation and body weight loss in mice treated with antibiotics, showing effects comparable to the control group not receiving antibiotics. The 50% dewaxed brown rice group showed the most notable improvements in stool weight and defecation frequency.
population_specificity: Mice administered antibiotics (vancomycin, metronidazole, and neomycin).
effective_dosage: Powdered feed containing 0-50% dewaxed brown rice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether eating glutinous brown rice (GBR) for 8 weeks could maintain improved glycemic control in outpatients with type 2 diabetes compared to white rice (WR).
results_summary: The study found that GBR significantly improved glycemic control, reducing hemoglobin A1c, glycoalbumin, and postprandial plasma glucose levels, with no adverse effects reported. No improvements were observed during the WR period.
population_specificity: Outpatients with type 2 diabetes (16 analyzed subjects).
effective_dosage: GBR as a staple food twice a day.
study_duration: 8 weeks per intervention (16 weeks total with crossover).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of soaking and high-pressure treatment (HPT) on water absorption, color, morphology, and cooked texture of brown rice.
results_summary: Soaking and HPT increased water absorption and lightness while reducing hardness and gumminess of cooked brown rice. Two-cycle HPT resulted in lighter color and softer texture due to more severe structural disruption of the bran layer compared to single-cycle HPT.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on brown rice samples).
effective_dosage: Soaking (30-50°C, 30 min); HPT (100-500 MPa, single or two cycles, total holding time 10 min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the best packaging method (vacuum-sealed, 60% CO2+40% N2, or 100% N2-sealed) to preserve the quality of germinated parboiled brown rice (GPBR) during storage.
results_summary: The 100% N2-sealed package best preserved GPBR quality, showing the highest DPPH scavenging activity and free fatty acid content, along with the least rancidity and brownness. All packaging conditions delayed fungal growth and kept aflatoxin B1 contamination very low (<0.82 μg/kg).
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on rice samples, not human subjects).
study_duration: 15 months of storage under ambient conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of microwave irradiation (MWI) in inactivating Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus on brown rice and barley while assessing its impact on quality parameters.
results_summary: MWI significantly reduced mould counts on brown rice and barley, with complete inactivation after 50 seconds. Quality parameters like colour and sensory attributes remained largely unaffected at shorter treatment times (up to 30 seconds), but some degradation occurred at longer durations (40-50 seconds).
population_specificity: Brown rice and barley samples contaminated with Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus.
effective_dosage: Microwave irradiation at 2450 MHz, 700 W for 10-50 seconds.
study_duration: Single treatment session with varying exposure times (10-50 seconds).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre-germinated brown rice (PGBR) could effectively treat metabolic syndrome by improving glucose and lipid metabolism in mice.
results_summary: The study found that PGBR improved blood pressure, biochemical parameters, and protein expressions related to glucose and lipid metabolism in mice fed a high-fat diet, suggesting it may help treat metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet for 16 weeks.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary carbohydrate replaced with PGBR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory potential of brown rice compared to other pigmented rice varieties in a healthy population.
results_summary: The study found that the brown rice variety did not affect any of the tested parameters, including antioxidant activity, MDA levels, or pro-inflammatory cytokines, unlike the purple and red rice varieties which showed significant effects.
population_specificity: Pre-screened healthy adults (n = 24).
effective_dosage: Not specified (volunteers consumed "a serve" of cooked pigmented rice).
study_duration: Blood samples were collected up to 4 hours post-consumption, with a one-week wash-out period between each rice variety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intake of brown rice lees (LB) reduces waist circumference and improves metabolic markers in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: The LB group showed a significant reduction in waist circumference and improved liver enzyme levels (aspartate transaminase and alanine transaminase) compared to the mixed-grain dietary product group.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a polyphenol-rich brown seaweed extract on fasting hyperlipidaemia, hyperglycaemia, inflammation, mood, and cognition in overweight or obese individuals with hypercholesterolaemia.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results as the study is pre-results; outcomes will assess serum cholesterol, triglycerides, glucose, insulin, inflammation markers, mood, and cognitive function after 12 weeks of intervention.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese individuals with hypercholesterolaemia (n=58).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiabetic and antioxidant effects of Butea monosperma flower extract in alloxan-induced diabetic mice.
results_summary: The extract significantly reduced blood glucose, improved lipid profiles, and restored antioxidant enzyme activity in diabetic mice, demonstrating both hypoglycemic and antioxidant properties. It also mitigated oxidative damage in the liver, pancreas, and kidneys.
population_specificity: Alloxan-induced diabetic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Butea monosperma leaf extract (BMEE) on diabetes and diabetes-induced oxidative stress in alloxan-induced diabetic mice.
results_summary: BMEE significantly reduced fasting blood glucose levels, improved antioxidant enzyme activities (CAT, GSH-Px, GSH), lowered TBARS levels, and improved serum lipid profiles in diabetic mice. However, SOD activity was not significantly improved.
population_specificity: Alloxan-induced diabetic male adult mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the chemopreventive effects of Butea monosperma extract on hepatic carcinogenesis and oxidative stress in male Wistar rats.
results_summary: Butea monosperma extract prevented oxidative stress, restored antioxidant enzyme levels, and reduced tumor incidence and markers of hepatic carcinogenesis in rats treated with 2-AAF. The protective effects were dose-dependent and confirmed histologically.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats
study_duration: Five consecutive days for initial toxicity study; longer duration for carcinogenesis study (exact length not specified)

study_goal: To investigate the effects of Xanthigen (containing brown seaweed extract fucoxanthin) on weight loss, body fat reduction, liver lipids, and blood biochemistry in obese, non-diabetic women with NAFLD or normal liver fat content.
results_summary: Xanthigen significantly reduced body weight, waist circumference, body fat, liver fat content, liver enzymes, serum triglycerides, and C-reactive protein. It also increased resting energy expenditure (REE) in NAFLD subjects.
population_specificity: Obese, non-diabetic premenopausal women with NAFLD (liver fat >11%) or normal liver fat (<6.5%).
effective_dosage: Xanthigen-600/2.4 mg (300 mg PSO + 300 mg brown seaweed extract with 2.4 mg fucoxanthin) and Xanthigen-400/1.6 mg (200 mg PSO + 200 mg brown seaweed extract with 1.6 mg fucoxanthin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anthelmintic effects of Butea monosperma seeds in sheep naturally infected with gastrointestinal nematodes.
results_summary: Butea monosperma seeds showed a dose- and time-dependent anthelmintic effect, with a maximum reduction of 78.4% in fecal egg count at the highest dose (3 g/kg) by day 10, compared to 99.1% reduction with the standard levamisole treatment.
population_specificity: Sheep naturally infected with mixed species of gastrointestinal nematodes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antihyperglycemic activity of Butea monosperma ethanolic extract (BMEE) in glucose-loaded and alloxan-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: BMEE significantly improved glucose tolerance and reduced blood glucose levels in diabetic rats. Repeated treatment also lowered serum cholesterol and improved HDL-cholesterol and albumin levels compared to the diabetic control group.
population_specificity: Alloxan-induced diabetic rats
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg (single dose and daily for 2 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-diarrhoeal potential of the ethanolic extract of Butea monosperma stem bark using experimental models in rats.
results_summary: The extract inhibited castor oil-induced diarrhoea and PGE(2)-induced enteropooling, and reduced gastrointestinal motility after charcoal meal administration, supporting its efficacy as a non-specific treatment for diarrhoea.
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and evaluate the anticonvulsant activity of the active principle (TBM) from Butea monosperma flowers.
results_summary: The study identified a triterpene (TBM) as the active anticonvulsant component, effective against seizures induced by MES, PTZ, electrical kindling, and Li-Pilo, but not strychnine or picrotoxin. TBM showed CNS depressant effects, and its efficacy slightly decreased with repeated use over 7 days.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal models based on methodology).
effective_dosage: PD(50) of 34.2+/-18.1 mg/kg (MES), increasing to 51.5+/-12.1 mg/kg after repeated use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the quality and safety of tahini (sesame butter) by fortifying it with Agaricus blazei to reduce microbial hazards and mycotoxins.
results_summary: Fortification with Agaricus blazei improved protein, fiber content, emulsion stability, and oxidative stability while eliminating pathogenic bacteria and reducing mycotoxins (aflatoxins and zearalenone) significantly. The 1.0% fortification showed the best results in safety and quality enhancement.
population_specificity: Local tahini samples (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of washing raw butter with hydrogen-rich water (HRW) on butter quality, focusing on acidity, peroxide value, and color.
results_summary: Washing butter with HRW reduced titratable acidity (TA) by 12% and resulted in lower acid degree values (ADV) and higher color notes compared to controls. HRW-treated samples also showed slower increases in TA and peroxide values during storage, indicating improved stability.
population_specificity: Raw butter samples (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (HRW prepared with H2 and/or Mg, but exact concentrations not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the food safety risks associated with peanut butter consumption, particularly Salmonella spp. and aflatoxin contamination, and discuss the effectiveness of current risk-minimization strategies.
results_summary: The study found that peanut butter poses significant food safety risks due to Salmonella spp. and aflatoxin contamination, with current inactivation methods being largely ineffective. Good manufacturing hygiene and avoiding contaminated peanuts are the primary viable strategies to mitigate these risks.
population_specificity: Global peanut butter consumers (general population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify molecular signatures in blood that differentiate dietary fat intakes, specifically comparing the effects of butter containing ruminant trans fatty acids (rTFA) to margarine with industrial trans fatty acids (iTFA).
results_summary: The study found that butter intake significantly altered serum fatty acid profiles and metabolome features compared to margarine, with trans vaccenic acid (C18:1 t11) being the most abundant TFA in butter. Gene expression was not differentially affected by the diets.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers aged 45-69 years (n=42).
effective_dosage: Butter provided 6.3 g TFA per 100 g, contributing up to 2% of energy intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the chronic effects of diets enriched with cocoa butter (CB) against palm olein and extra virgin olive oil on lipid profiles in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found that cocoa butter had similar lipid responses to palm olein and extra virgin olive oil, with minor statistical differences in LDL cholesterol (CB > EVOO) and HDL cholesterol (PO > CB).
population_specificity: 40 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: Not specified (baked products prepared with test fats)
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention with 2-week washout periods

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the oligosaccharide specificity of Butea monosperma agglutinin (BMA) and its utility in identifying malignancy-associated alterations in alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) sugar chains.
results_summary: BMA showed the highest affinity for exposed Gal residues of biantennary complex-type oligosaccharides, with reduced affinity in the presence of sialyl residues and bisecting GlcNAc. BMA did not recognize Neu5Ac substitutions, making it useful for detecting malignancy-related AFP sugar chain alterations.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on AFP oligosaccharides)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the thermal death kinetics of Salmonella enterica Enteritidis PT 30 in peanut butter under varying moisture contents and temperatures to develop effective pasteurization processes.
results_summary: The study found that higher moisture content and higher treatment temperature reduced the decimal reduction time (D-value) of S. Enteritidis in peanut butter, with the first-order kinetic model being suitable for pasteurization process validation.
population_specificity: Peanut butter samples with moisture contents of 3.1% and 5.6% (dry basis).
study_duration: Not specified (kinetic study without explicit intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of cocoa butter-based ketogenic and low-fat diets on weight loss and glucose homeostasis in obese mice.
results_summary: The ketogenic diet (85% cocoa butter) did not significantly improve body fat loss or glucose tolerance in obese mice, while the low-fat diet (10% cocoa butter) led to beneficial body composition changes and improved glucose tolerance.
population_specificity: Obese male and female mice
effective_dosage: 60% cocoa butter (high-fat diet), 85% cocoa butter (ketogenic diet), 10% cocoa butter (low-fat diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bacuri seed butter on body weight, growth, lipid profile, atherosclerotic indices, and liver function in dyslipidemic hamsters.
results_summary: Bacuri seed butter at 25 and 50 mg/kg/day increased HDL-c and decreased LDL-c, reducing atherosclerotic risk indices, but did not affect total cholesterol, triglycerides, body weight, growth, or liver function.
population_specificity: Dyslipidemic male hamsters.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify and compare the enantiomeric distributions of δ- and γ-lactones in butter, fermented butter, and margarine, and assess the impact of heat treatment on these distributions.
results_summary: The study found that butter and fermented butter contained specific (R)-form lactones, while margarine had racemic forms, indicating synthetic additives. Heat treatment altered lactone distributions, with most δ-lactones remaining in the (R)-form, while γ-lactones appeared in racemic forms except for γ-dodecalactone.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on food samples, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study analyzed food composition, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ghee butter from bovine colostrum (GBBC) exhibits anti-inflammatory effects in a mouse model of acute pancreatitis (AP).
results_summary: GBBC administration reduced myeloperoxidase (MPO) activity in the pancreas and lungs, decreased microscopical severity of AP, and normalized pancreatic enzyme activity. The anti-inflammatory effects appeared to involve FFAR1 and FFAR4 receptors.
population_specificity: Mice with experimentally induced acute pancreatitis.
effective_dosage: Oral gavage every 12 hours (specific dosage not provided).
study_duration: 72 hours from the first L-arginine injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of extended light/dark (L/D) cycle periods on butter leaf lettuce growth, biomass, and nutritional quality in a controlled artificial light environment.
results_summary: Abnormal L/D cycles increased lettuce shoot dry weight (34-83%), improved light and electric use efficiency, and enhanced nutritional quality (e.g., higher vitamin C, soluble sugar, and crude fiber content). The optimal treatment for biomass was L24/D12, while L120/D60 maximized energy efficiency and nutritional benefits.
population_specificity: Butter leaf lettuce grown in a plant factory with artificial light (PFAL).
effective_dosage: Light exposure durations: L16/D8 (control), L24/D12, L48/D24, L96/D48, L120/D60.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Vibigaba (germinated brown rice) contributes to the maintenance of normal blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found no established cause-and-effect relationship between Vibigaba consumption and blood pressure maintenance due to methodological limitations and insufficient data. The Panel concluded that the evidence provided was inadequate to substantiate the claim.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore older adults' perceptions of the benefits and drawbacks of chiropractic care and exercise therapy for spine-related outcomes, focusing on what makes such treatments worthwhile.
results_summary: Participants viewed chiropractic care as effective for improving spinal pain and symptom control, while exercise therapy was noted for enhancing long-term self-efficacy and self-management. Both interventions were considered complementary for managing spine-related disability.
population_specificity: Older adults with spinal disability
study_duration: Not specified (long-term vs. short-term management was compared)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ashtanga Ghrita (AG), a formulation containing clarified cow butter (ghee), could counteract scopolamine-induced dementia and brain oxidative stress in rats.
results_summary: AG significantly protected rats from scopolamine-induced behavioral dysfunction and brain biochemical alterations, demonstrating neuroprotective effects through enhanced brain antioxidant activity. Microbial load and heavy metals were within permissible limits, and phytochemical analysis confirmed the presence of beneficial compounds.
population_specificity: Rats (n=6/group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to scientifically evaluate the chemistry, quality attributes, utilization, preparation methods, and storage of traditional Indian cultured butter (makkhan) to identify challenges and opportunities for improvement in production.
results_summary: The study identified conventional practices as a limitation in butter production and suggested mechanized approaches to improve quality and processing. No specific efficacy outcomes were reported, but the focus was on identifying areas for improvement.
population_specificity: Traditional Indian cultured butter (makkhan) production in village households of the Indian subcontinent.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize traditional therapeutic applications of shea butter for dermatologic ailments in Sub-Saharan Africa and evaluate patterns of use.
results_summary: The study identified 24 dermatologic uses of shea butter across 30 references, with scabies, wound healing, and umbilical cord care being the most frequently investigated conditions. Shea butter was commonly used in combination with other ingredients, particularly Elaeis guineensis (African oil palm).
population_specificity: Sub-Saharan African populations using traditional medicine for dermatologic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the burn healing effects of imported South African raw Shea butter and commercially available Shea butter samples in the Libyan market.
results_summary: Shea butter T1 induced an immune response with inflammatory cells, while T2 showed slight healing with granulation tissue formation. Raw Shea butter had a negative effect, but the Polish sample with additives demonstrated therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats (6-8 weeks old, 350-400 g).
effective_dosage: Thin film applied daily (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers investigated the effect of post weld heat treatment (PWHT) on the microstructure and corrosion kinetics of butter welded Nickel Alloy 617 and 12Cr steel.
results_summary: The study found that PWHT increased the corrosion susceptibility of the butter weld due to reduced Cr content in the heat-affected zone, resulting in higher corrosion rates. The corrosion activation parameters were determined using Arrhenius plots.
population_specificity: Nickel Alloy 617 and 12Cr steel materials (not human or biological).
study_duration: PWHT was conducted at 730 °C for 4 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of cocoa butter (COB) with other dietary fats (palm olein and soybean oil) on liver fat concentration and cardiometabolic health outcomes in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that cocoa butter did not differentially affect liver fat concentration, adipose tissue amounts, or most cardiometabolic health outcomes compared to other fats. However, it decreased body fat mass relative to palm olein and had inconsistent effects on serum lipids.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 20-45 with a BMI of 18.5-27.5 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Test fats contributed 20% of total energy intake (33% total fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the enrichment of c9,t11-CLA from butter and investigate its preventive effect against breast cancer in vivo.
results_summary: The study found that c9,t11-CLA concentration in butter increased more than 10 times via urea complexation, and dietary c9,t11-CLA reduced tumor weight, volume, and incidence by up to 50%, while also decreasing progesterone receptor and Ki-67 expression.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo study, likely animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physicochemical properties of tengkawang butter and assess its suitability for the food industry by reducing acidity and peroxide values using activated bentonite.
results_summary: The study found that activated bentonite significantly reduced acidity and peroxide values in tengkawang butter, meeting industry standards. The main fatty acids identified were palmitic, stearic, and oleic acids, indicating potential for food applications.
population_specificity: Tengkawang fat samples from Nanga Yen and Sintang regions.
effective_dosage: 1% phosphoric acid for degumming, 1 M NaOH 10% w/w for neutralization, and 0.5 M HCl or thermal activation for bentonite treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ALA-biofortified butter on lipid metabolism and thermogenic functions in brown adipose tissue (BAT) compared to conventional butter or margarine.
results_summary: ALA-biofortified butter reduced BAT whitening, increased thermogenesis in response to cold, and promoted BAT remodeling through n-3 LC PUFA bioconversion, fatty acid elongation/desaturation, and mitochondrial biogenesis.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice fed a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: 45% of calories from fat (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the lactone content in butter, fermented butter, and margarine, and assess the impact of heat treatment on lactone levels.
results_summary: The study found that butter and fermented butter contained more lactones than margarine, with heat treatment doubling lactone content in butter and fermented butter but not affecting margarine. Fermented butter showed greater increases in lactone content after heating compared to regular butter.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or food product analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness, safety, and compliance of an intensive plant-based butter moisturizing cream (Venusia ® Max) in improving quality of life and reducing skin dryness in Indian patients with psoriasis.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in mean DLQI (66.7%) and DASI (84.6%) scores at week 4, indicating improved quality of life and reduced skin dryness. The cream demonstrated good safety and compliance, with no serious adverse events or deaths reported.
population_specificity: Indian patients with psoriasis aged 18-75 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a beeswax-olive oil-butter (BOB) mixture could improve wound healing in second-degree burns by modulating TGF-β1 and VEGF-α expression.
results_summary: BOB treatment increased TGF-β1 and VEGF-α expression, enhanced skin regeneration, fibroblast activity, and wound contraction, outperforming both the untreated burn group and silver sulfadiazine treatment.
population_specificity: Rats with induced second-degree burns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding peanut butter to a high-glycemic index breakfast meal reduces the glycemic response in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that adding 32 g of peanut butter significantly reduced the blood glucose spike and overall glycemic response compared to the control meal, with lower blood glucose levels at 15, 30, and 60 minutes post-meal.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy adults aged 24.1 ± 3.5 years.
effective_dosage: 32 g (2 tbsp) of peanut butter added to the meal.
study_duration: Two days (one control day, one treatment day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the antioxidant and antimicrobial effects of walnut kernel septum membranes hydroalcohol extract (WHE) in traditional butter (TB) and compare it with synthetic antioxidants like BHT and tocopherol.
results_summary: WHE showed significant antioxidant and antimicrobial activity in butter, with the 0.5% concentration being most effective. It reduced peroxide values, free fatty acids, and microbial growth, though sensory attributes were highest in the control and 0.05% WHE samples.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general butter consumers).
effective_dosage: 0.05%, 0.1%, and 0.5% WHE; 200 mg/kg BHT and tocopherol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of high-intensity ultrasound (HIU) on the physical properties of cream and butter.
results_summary: HIU treatment of cream for 10-60 s increased butter hardness, with the hardest butter obtained after 10 s of sonication. HIU also altered melting behavior and crystallization patterns in butter, though some effects diminished after 24 h of storage.
population_specificity: Heavy cream (40% fat) and resulting butter.
study_duration: Immediate effects measured post-production and after 24 h of storage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate baking as an adequate lethality step in controlling Salmonella and Listeria monocytogenes during the production of peanut butter-filled pretzels and whole wheat pita chips.
results_summary: The study found that baking at 350°F significantly reduced Salmonella and L. monocytogenes, with ≥5-log reductions achieved in 15.5-17.5 minutes and pathogens undetectable after 25-30 minutes. Both products baked to saleable quality were deemed safe from these pathogens.
population_specificity: Peanut butter-filled pretzel and whole wheat pita chip dough samples.
effective_dosage: Baking temperatures of 300°F and 350°F for durations of 0, 5, 10, 17, 25, and 30 minutes.
study_duration: Single baking sessions with varying durations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of cocoa butter (CB), palm olein (POL), and extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) on lipid profiles and LDL subfractions in a healthy young Chinese population.
results_summary: The study found that cocoa butter had almost identical effects on serum lipids compared to POL and EVOO, with no significant differences in most indices among the three test oils. Only the serum triglyceride level of the POL-Diet was significantly lower than that of the EVOO-Diet.
population_specificity: Young, healthy Chinese adults (72 subjects initially, 67 completed).
effective_dosage: Each test oil accounted for approximately 40% of total fat intake (~11.3% of total energy supply).
study_duration: 18-week randomized crossover trial (4-week experimental periods with 2-week washout intervals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize a topical emulgel containing amphotericin B and bacuri butter, evaluating its antileishmanial activity and potential for topical use.
results_summary: The formulations showed promising antileishmanial action, with synergism between bacuri butter and amphotericin B, reduced cytotoxicity to host cells, and suitable physicochemical properties for topical application.
population_specificity: In vitro assays using promastigotes forms of Leishmania major and macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of butter, coconut oil, and olive oil on blood lipid profiles, weight, fat distribution, and metabolic markers in healthy adults.
results_summary: Butter significantly increased LDL-C and TC/HDL-C ratio compared to coconut oil and olive oil, but no significant differences were observed in weight, BMI, central adiposity, or blood pressure among the groups.
population_specificity: Healthy men and women aged 50-75 years, predominantly European Caucasian, with no history of cancer, cardiovascular disease, or diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of vegetable shortening and cocoa butter as vehicles for intraperitoneal cortisol implants in juvenile brown trout.
results_summary: Vegetable shortening provided long-term cortisol elevation (3, 6, and 9 days post-treatment), while cocoa butter was better for short-term elevation (only at 3 days). Plasma cortisol and glucose levels were higher with vegetable shortening than cocoa butter.
population_specificity: Juvenile brown trout (Salmo trutta) in north temperate freshwater environments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document the clinical symptoms and effective management of jojoba butter ingestion, which is known to be cyanogenic and inedible.
results_summary: The study found that ingestion of homemade jojoba seed butter led to restlessness and gastrointestinal complaints in a patient, requiring symptomatic treatment including fluid resuscitation, lorazepam, and diphenhydramine.
population_specificity: A single patient who ingested homemade jojoba seed butter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the environmental impacts associated with the manufacture of butter in the Republic of Ireland, focusing on energy consumption and emissions.
results_summary: The study found that energy consumption contributes significantly to the global warming and terrestrial acidification potential of butter production (78% and 96%, respectively). Packaging materials and wastewater treatment also have notable environmental impacts.
population_specificity: Dairy processing factories in the Republic of Ireland (5 factories, 4 of which produce butter).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of consuming equal amounts of saturated fatty acids (SFAs) from cheese and butter on cardiometabolic risk factors, particularly HDL and LDL cholesterol levels.
results_summary: Butter consumption increased LDL-cholesterol levels more than cheese, especially in individuals with high baseline LDL cholesterol, but had similar effects on HDL cholesterol. No significant differences were observed in inflammation markers, blood pressure, or insulin-glucose homeostasis between butter and other diets.
population_specificity: 92 men and women with abdominal obesity and relatively low HDL-cholesterol concentrations.
effective_dosage: SFAs from butter constituted 12.4-12.6% of total calories in the diet.
study_duration: 4 weeks per diet intervention, with 4-week washout periods between diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a reliable, sensitive, and economical method using NIR spectroscopy and chemometric models to detect and quantify tallow adulteration in clarified butter samples.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a highly sensitive NIR spectroscopy method combined with chemometric models (PCA, PLSDA, PLSR) to detect and quantify tallow adulteration in clarified butter, with excellent performance (RMSEP of 1.537% and correlation factor of 0.95). The method was robust, non-destructive, and capable of detecting less than 1.5% tallow adulteration.
population_specificity: Clarified butter samples (pure and adulterated with tallow at varying percentages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate ghee (clarified butter) as a delivery vehicle for the chemotherapeutic drug temozolomide (TMZ) in solid lipid nanoparticles (GSLN) and assess its anti-proliferative effects on glioblastoma cells.
results_summary: Ghee-based nanoparticles (GSLN) effectively encapsulated TMZ (~70% efficiency) and demonstrated controlled drug release (~53% in 5 hours). TMZ-loaded GSLN significantly reduced glioblastoma cell viability while improving drug diffusion across endothelial cell monolayers compared to free TMZ.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC) and glioblastoma LN-229 cells (in vitro study).
study_duration: 3 days for viability assessment; 5 hours for release kinetics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how manipulating fat content, holding time, and churning temperature could improve the rheological properties, spreadability, and health profile of butter.
results_summary: Increasing fat content (40% to 45%), extending holding time (3h to 5h), and lowering churning temperature (12°C to 10°C) resulted in softer butter with improved spreadability, reduced melting temperature (36°C to 32°C), and lower trans fatty acid content (3.2% to 1.87%).
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on butter production).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (processing parameters studied, not dosage).
study_duration: Not specified (processing time described, not intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant effects of butylatedhydroxyanisole (BHA) and orange peel powder extract in ghee under different storage temperatures.
results_summary: Ghee with orange peel extract showed stronger antioxidant activity, lower peroxide value, and reduced oxidative deterioration compared to BHA and control samples, especially at higher storage temperatures.
population_specificity: Ghee samples stored under controlled conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gestational exposure to high dietary butter fat (HFB) and/or bisphenol A (BPA) disrupts spermatogenesis in adulthood.
results_summary: Adult males with gestational exposure to HFB, BPA, or HFB+BPA exhibited impaired spermatogenesis, while HFO or HFO+BPA exposure did not. The HFB+BPA group showed more severe effects, including atrophy.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats (male offspring exposed during pregnancy).
effective_dosage: 10kcal% butter fat (AIN), 39kcal% butter fat (HFB), or 39kcal% olive oil (HFO), with or without BPA (25μg/kg body weight/day).
study_duration: Gestational exposure (during pregnancy) and follow-up to postnatal day 210 or 18 months.
interactions: BPA (xenoestrogen) exacerbated the negative effects of HFB.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability, efficacy, and skin biophysiological effects of a cream/cleanser containing shea butter extract for treating childhood atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The cream was rated as "very good" or "good" by 74% of patients, with improvements in pruritus and quality of life in the accepting group. No significant difference in efficacy or acceptability was found compared to a ceramide-precursor moisturizer.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how butter affects the pharmacokinetics and metabolism of tea polyphenols, specifically catechins, in vivo.
results_summary: Butter decreased the plasma concentration of free catechins but increased conjugated catechins, indicating altered metabolism without affecting total absorption. Butter also significantly increased fecal and biliary excretion of catechins.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of 915 MHz microwave treatment at different power levels in reducing Salmonella contamination in peanut butter.
results_summary: Higher microwave power (6 kW) for 5 minutes significantly reduced Salmonella populations (3.24-4.26 log CFU/g), while lower power levels (2-4 kW) showed smaller reductions. The treatment did not affect the acid, peroxide, or color values of peanut butter.
population_specificity: Peanut butter inoculated with Salmonella enterica serovars (Senftenberg, Typhimurium, Tennessee).
effective_dosage: Microwave treatment at 2, 4, and 6 kW for 5 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of moderate butter intake, moderate olive oil intake, and a habitual diet on blood lipids, hsCRP, glucose, and insulin.
results_summary: Butter intake increased total and LDL cholesterol more than olive oil and the habitual diet, but also raised HDL cholesterol compared to the habitual diet. No significant differences were observed for triacylglycerol, hsCRP, insulin, or glucose concentrations.
population_specificity: 47 healthy men and women (70% women) with a mean age of 40.4 years and a mean BMI of 23.5 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 4.5% of energy from butter or refined olive oil.
study_duration: 5-week intervention periods with a 14-day run-in period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a diet high in saturated fats (using butter) versus monounsaturated fats (using extra virgin olive oil) on anthropometric, metabolic, and lipid profiles in postmenopausal women.
