results_summary: The butter-based (SAT) diet increased total cholesterol, LDL-C, and non-HDL cholesterol, raising cardiovascular risk, while the olive oil-based (MONO) diet improved HDL-C and reduced markers of metabolic syndrome and coronary heart disease risk.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with an average BMI of 29.8 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Not specified (butter was part of a diet with 38% fat, 20% saturated fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether feeding rats a diet enriched with CLA in butter affects PLA2 activity and gene expression in brain tissue, with potential implications for memory enhancement.
results_summary: Rats fed a high CLA butter diet showed increased hippocampal mRNA levels for specific PLA2 isoforms and higher enzymatic activity of all PLA2 groups, which correlated significantly with improved memory performance. The findings suggest CLA-enriched butter may have therapeutic potential for Alzheimer's disease.
population_specificity: Wistar rats
effective_dosage: Not specified (CLA-enriched butter vs. low CLA butter and control diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a cleaning and sanitation procedure involving hot oil and isopropanol to decontaminate peanut butter processing equipment contaminated with Salmonella.
results_summary: The study found that hot oil alone was insufficient to inactivate Salmonella, but a two-step treatment with hot oil followed by isopropanol sanitization eliminated Salmonella from contaminated equipment. No Salmonella was detected in environmental samples after the sanitization process.
population_specificity: Pilot-scale peanut butter processing equipment.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (cleaning procedure involved hot oil at 90°C for 2 h and 60% isopropanol for 1 h).
study_duration: 3 hours (2 h hot oil + 1 h sanitization).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the stress response and effectiveness of drug administration via peanut butter pellets versus traditional oral gavage in mice.
results_summary: Peanut butter pellets resulted in significantly lower stress (measured by corticosterone levels) compared to gavage, while maintaining expected pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, including effective Aβ40 lowering in PSAPP mice.
population_specificity: Transgenic mice (PSAPP mice) used as models for neurodegenerative disorders.
effective_dosage: Not specified (drug formulation details not provided).
study_duration: Chronic 30-day dosing for the BACE inhibitor study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high hydrostatic pressure processing (HPP) and formulation modifications (water activity adjustment and nisin addition) could effectively inactivate Salmonella in peanut butter.
results_summary: HPP alone or combined with nisin did not sufficiently inactivate Salmonella in peanut butter, achieving only a 1.7 log reduction. Increased water activity improved log reduction, but peanut oil addition reduced HPP effectiveness.
population_specificity: Peanut butter samples modified with water, peanut oil, or nisin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the presence and concentration of macrocyclic lactone residues (abamectin, doramectin, ivermectin, and moxidectin) in commercial butter samples.
results_summary: Ivermectin was detected in 89.5% of samples (0.3–119.4 µg/kg), doramectin in 76.3% (0.6–64.7 µg/kg), and abamectin in 55.2% (0.7–4.5 µg/kg). No moxidectin was found, and 76.3% of samples contained residues of more than one macrocyclic lactone.
population_specificity: Commercial butter samples purchased in the metropolitan area of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (June–September 2013).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of dl-β-amino-n-butyric acid (BABA) elicitation on polyphenol oxidase (PPO) activity in lettuce leaves, not Butter.
results_summary: The study found that BABA-elicited lettuce showed altered PPO enzyme affinity, temperature sensitivity, and inhibitor response compared to control plants, with additional PPO isoforms observed in treated samples.
population_specificity: Lettuce leaves (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunomodulating effect of a nutrient-rich diet including full-fat butter on children with non-specific elevated IgE.
results_summary: The study found a greater decrease in IgE levels in the intervention group (9.2 kU/l) compared to the control group (0.1 kU/l), but this effect was not significant when accounting for vitamin D supplementation. Symptom improvement was reported by 53.2% of the intervention group versus 28.6% of controls.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-18 years with non-specific elevated IgE.

study_goal: The study does not address Butter; it examines the effects of chemical elicitors (arachidonic acid, jasmonic acid, and abscisic acid) on phytochemical levels, antiradical activity, and quality of lettuce.
results_summary: The study found that certain elicitors increased phytochemical levels (e.g., phenolics, flavonoids, chlorophyll, carotenoids, vitamin C) and antiradical activity in lettuce without affecting sensory quality.
population_specificity: Lettuce (plant study, not human or animal)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on lettuce, not Butter)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of gamma irradiation in reducing Salmonella Typhimurium in peanut butter products with different water activities and storage conditions.
results_summary: Gamma irradiation significantly reduced S. Typhimurium levels in peanut butter, with higher doses (3 kGy) achieving greater reductions. Product C (highest water activity) showed the fastest pathogen reduction, and storage at 25°C accelerated pathogen death compared to 4°C. Sensory quality remained largely unaffected.
population_specificity: Peanut butter products (types A, B, and C) with varying water activities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the factors influencing the structure and rheology of milk fat-based products like butter, particularly in the context of low-fat product demand.
results_summary: The study found that butter's microstructure and rheological behavior are influenced by multiple factors, including thermal treatment, water content, and chemical composition. Postcrystallization during storage strengthens the fat crystal network, reducing initial microstructural differences.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dairy product research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the mechanisms of fat crystallization during cream ripening and churning to optimize butter production.
results_summary: Longer ripening time (5h vs. 0h) increased butter grain size (91 vs. 52 µm), viscosity (5.3 vs. 1.3 Pa·s), and solid fat content (41 vs. 13%). Churning time decreased significantly after 0.5h of ripening (16.23 min vs. 22.9 min).
population_specificity: Cream samples (no human subjects).
study_duration: Ripening times up to 5h, churning times measured.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of butter from mountain-pasture grazing cows versus conventionally fed cows on metabolic syndrome risk markers.
results_summary: The study found no differences in blood lipids, lipoproteins, inflammation markers, insulin, glucose, or glucose tolerance between the two butter groups. However, baseline phytanic acid levels strongly correlated with total and LDL cholesterol.
population_specificity: 38 healthy subjects
effective_dosage: 39 g fat from test butter daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of radio-frequency (RF) heating in inactivating Salmonella Typhimurium and Escherichia coli O157:H7 in peanut butter cracker sandwiches and assess its impact on product quality.
results_summary: RF heating significantly reduced pathogen levels (4.29-5.32 log CFU/g) in both creamy and chunky peanut butter without significantly affecting color or sensory characteristics.
population_specificity: Peanut butter cracker sandwiches (commercial peanut butter samples).
effective_dosage: 90 seconds of RF treatment at 27.12 MHz.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how cream heat treatment, storage temperatures, and fat globule presence affect butter's crystallization behavior, rheological properties, and microstructure.
results_summary: Butter from non-matured cream formed mainly α- and β'-crystals, while matured cream led to a transition to β'- and β-crystals. Slow-cooled butter had a weaker crystal network and lower elastic modulus, but fat globule presence did not significantly alter rheological properties.
population_specificity: Laboratory-scale produced butter (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal rate of flaxseed supplementation to improve the fatty acid profile of milk and dairy products like butter without negatively affecting production characteristics.
results_summary: Increasing extruded flaxseed supplementation improved the fatty acid profile of butter by reducing saturated fats and increasing C18:3n-3, leading to improved spreadability without affecting production parameters. Flaxseed processing did not impact butter texture or production.
population_specificity: Mid- to late-lactation Holstein cows
effective_dosage: 0, 0.91, 1.81, and 2.72 kg/d of extruded flaxseed; 1.81 kg/d of ground flaxseed

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different feeding regimens (pasture vs. silage-based TMR) and lipid supplements (saturated fatty acids vs. rumen-protected microalgae) affect the fatty acid composition and oxidation of milk and butter.
results_summary: The study found that feeding rumen-protected microalgae increased DHA content in milk and butter but reduced oxidative stability in butter under UV exposure. Fatty acid composition in butter mirrored that of milk, with higher polyunsaturated FA levels in PAS+ treatment and higher saturated FA levels in TMR⁻.
population_specificity: 8 mid-lactation Holstein cows
effective_dosage: 22 g of DHA/100 g of fatty acids (microalgae supplement)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of argemone oil (AO) and butter yellow (BY), common adulterants in edible oil, on free radical generation and cell proliferation signaling pathways in gall bladder (GB) cells.
results_summary: AO and BY at noncytotoxic doses increased COX-2 expression and activated cell proliferation pathways (ErbB2, AKT, ERK, JNK) in GB cells, with AO also elevating ROS and RNS levels. The study suggests these adulterants may contribute to gall bladder cancer via different mechanisms.
population_specificity: Primary cells of gall bladder (GB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the chemical adduct of diacetyl (a butter flavorant) with DNA nucleobases and assess its mutagenic and cytotoxic effects.
results_summary: The study found that diacetyl selectively modifies guanosine residues in DNA, disrupts ternary DNA structure, and induces dose-dependent apoptosis in SH-SY5Y cells. Traditional carbonyl scavengers like d-penicillamine mitigated diacetyl toxicity.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y cells (a human neuroblastoma cell line)
interactions: d-penicillamine, metformin, 2-thiobarbituric acid (carbonyl scavengers) mitigated diacetyl toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of diets rich in hard cheese or butter on blood pressure, serum lipids, and other metabolic markers, and to examine differences in fecal fat excretion.
results_summary: The study found that cheese lowered LDL cholesterol compared to butter but did not increase LDL cholesterol relative to a habitual diet. Fecal fat excretion did not differ between cheese and butter consumption.
population_specificity: 49 men and women
effective_dosage: 13% of energy intake from butter or cheese
study_duration: Two 6-week crossover periods with a 14-day run-in period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of butter naturally enriched in ruminant trans fatty acids (rTFAs) on plasma lipid concentrations in healthy women.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of the rTFA-enriched butter on total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, or triglycerides, but observed a small reduction in HDL-cholesterol, particularly in overweight women.
population_specificity: 61 healthy women aged 19-70 years.
effective_dosage: 3.7 g/d rTFAs (1.5% of daily energy) vs. 0.9 g/d (0.3% of daily energy) in the control diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the survival rates of Salmonella enterica and Escherichia coli O157:H7 in peanut butter under different formulations and water activity conditions.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in bacterial survival rates, with higher carbohydrate content and lower incubation temperature increasing bacterial survival during storage but decreasing resistance to heat treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on bacterial survival in peanut butter).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cocoa butter implants on the growth of female brown trout and the size of their offspring, as well as the impact of cortisol treatment on adult mortality.
results_summary: Cocoa butter implants during egg development affected female brown trout growth and reduced offspring size, while cortisol treatment increased adult mortality. The study advises caution in using implants for maternal hormonal influence studies in fish.
population_specificity: Female brown trout (Salmo trutta)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of butter and cold-pressed turnip rapeseed oil on serum lipids, oxidized LDL, and arterial elasticity in men with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Butter consumption resulted in higher total cholesterol (8%) and LDL cholesterol (11%) compared to rapeseed oil, with no significant differences in arterial elasticity. Oxidized LDL levels were also higher with butter (16%).
population_specificity: 37 men with metabolic syndrome

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the levels of aflatoxin contamination in peanut butter samples from Khartoum State, Sudan, and evaluate their compliance with international safety regulations.
results_summary: All 43 peanut butter samples were contaminated with aflatoxins, with levels exceeding international safety standards. AFB1 and AFG1 were the most prevalent and highest in concentration, posing serious health risks to consumers.
population_specificity: Peanut butter samples from Khartoum State, Sudan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of electron beam (e-beam) radiation on the survival of Salmonella Tennessee and Typhimurium in creamy peanut butter over a 14-day storage period.
results_summary: E-beam irradiation reduced Salmonella counts in peanut butter, with significant initial differences in recovery rates between strains and media, though these differences did not persist. Salmonella Typhimurium showed significant reductions by day 14, while Salmonella Tennessee survival was maintained, indicating strain-specific responses to e-beam treatment.
population_specificity: Salmonella serotypes Tennessee (ATCC 10722) and Typhimurium (ATCC 14028) in creamy peanut butter.
effective_dosage: E-beam doses ranging from 0 to 3.1 kGy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of high-pressure processing (HPP) in reducing Salmonella Typhimurium contamination in peanut butter and related model systems.
results_summary: HPP achieved minimal reduction (<1.0 log) in natural peanut butter but showed higher efficacy (1.0-1.7 log reduction) in peanut flour/oil mixtures and significant reduction (6.7 log) in peanut flour/water mixtures. Oil had a protective effect, limiting HPP's effectiveness in peanut butter.
population_specificity: Peanut butter and peanut flour model systems inoculated with Salmonella Typhimurium.
study_duration: 28 days (for viability study at room temperature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the theoretical effects of substituting plant-based fats (from margarine) for animal-based fat (from butter) on the risk of atherosclerosis-related cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: Substituting butter or stick margarine with tub margarine was associated with a lower risk of myocardial infarction (HRs = 0.95 and 0.91). Similar trends were observed for total coronary heart disease, ischemic stroke, and atherosclerosis-related CVD, though with wider confidence intervals.
population_specificity: 71,410 women aged 50-79 years.
effective_dosage: 1 teaspoon/day substitution of margarine for butter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of regular butter versus butter enriched with c9,t11-CLA and VA on plasma lipids in growing pigs.
results_summary: Pigs fed CLA+VA-enriched butter showed increased serum concentrations of alpha-linolenic acid and decreased myristic and palmitic acid compared to regular butter, but no significant differences in plasma lipoprotein profiles were observed.
population_specificity: Female growing pigs
effective_dosage: 5.0 g c9,t11-CLA plus 15.1 g VA or 1.3 g c9,t11-CLA plus 3.6 g VA daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a peanut butter-based therapeutic food (chiponde) in improving nutritional status and chemotherapy response in malnourished children with Wilms tumor in Malawi.
results_summary: Chiponde supplementation led to a >5% increase in corrected weight in 7 of 18 patients during preoperative chemotherapy, and better nutritional progress correlated with improved tumor response to chemotherapy. However, acute malnutrition remained prevalent despite intervention.
population_specificity: Malnourished children with Wilms tumor in Malawi.
effective_dosage: Not specified (locally made ready-to-use therapeutic peanut butter-based food).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if washing caprine cream before churning improves phospholipid and MFGM protein purification in buttermilk and butter serum.
results_summary: The washing treatment significantly reduced casein content and increased phospholipids-to-protein ratios in buttermilk and butter serum, though ratios were lower in caprine cream compared to bovine cream. Phospholipids were concentrated more in butter serum than buttermilk, yielding extracts with up to 180 g/kg (caprine) and 240 g/kg (bovine) phospholipids.
population_specificity: Caprine and bovine cream samples.

study_goal: The abstract does not address the study's goal regarding Butter.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Butter.
population_specificity: Not specified in the context of Butter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pulsed ultraviolet (PUV) light treatment could reduce the allergenic properties of peanut extracts and liquid peanut butter.
results_summary: PUV light treatment reduced the solubility of a major peanut allergen (63 kDa) and decreased IgE binding by 7-fold compared to untreated samples, while boiling had little effect. The formation of insoluble aggregates was responsible for the reduced allergen levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on peanut extracts and liquid peanut butter)
effective_dosage: 3 pulses/s, 14.6 cm from lamp, 4 min (extract) or 3 min (liquid peanut butter)
study_duration: Single treatment session (4 min for extract, 3 min for liquid peanut butter)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a standard test meal versus a novel test meal on cPDR (likely a measure of digestion or absorption) in healthy controls.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in cPDR between the standard test meal and the novel test meal, with mean values of 39.39% and 39.93%, respectively. The statistical analysis confirmed no meaningful difference (p=0.68).
population_specificity: 14 healthy controls

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how a Western-type diet (WTD), including butter, impacts intestinal and extra-intestinal inflammation and mucosal immunity.
results_summary: The study associates high intake of butter as part of a WTD with metabolic and chronic inflammatory conditions of the gastrointestinal tract, promoting inflammation and altering mucosal immunity.
population_specificity: General Western population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of increasing extruded linseed in dairy cow diets on milk fat yield, fatty acid composition, and butter properties.
results_summary: Increasing extruded linseed linearly decreased milk fat content and globule size while increasing unsaturated fatty acids, particularly alpha-linolenic acid and trans FA. Butter texture improved, but there were no significant effects on color or sensory properties, with LIN2 causing butter-making challenges.
population_specificity: Thirty-six Prim'Holstein cows at 104 days in milk.
effective_dosage: 2.1% (LIN1) or 4.3% (LIN2) extruded linseed in the diet on a dry matter basis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify vitamin E intake levels and plasma concentrations, assessing dietary vitamin E adequacy in Irish adults, with a focus on major dietary sources like butter.
results_summary: Butter and spreadable fats were identified as one of the main dietary sources of vitamin E. The study found that dietary vitamin E intake significantly affected plasma tocopherol concentrations, but supplements were the primary contributor to overall intake.
population_specificity: Irish adults (representative cohort from the National Adult Nutrition Survey).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether treatment with butter fat (as a control) affected vitamin D status and inflammatory markers in severely obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that butter fat treatment did not significantly affect vitamin D status in severely obese patients, and no significant changes in inflammatory markers were reported for the butter fat group.
population_specificity: Severely obese (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m²), non-diabetic patients.
effective_dosage: Same amount as the n-3 PUFA group (3.36 g/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different whey protein fractions added to a high-fat meal (containing butter) on postprandial lipid and hormone responses in type 2 diabetic subjects.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in triglyceride responses between meals with different whey protein fractions. Whey isolate and whey hydrolysate caused a higher insulin response compared to other protein fractions.
population_specificity: 12 type 2 diabetic subjects
effective_dosage: 100 g of butter per test meal
study_duration: Single meal intervention with measurements up to 8 hours postprandially

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the dietary shift toward increased consumption of saturated fatty acids (SFAs), including ghee (clarified butter), and its potential metabolic and glycemic consequences in developing countries.
results_summary: The study highlights an increase in SFA intake from sources like ghee in South Asia and South-East Asia, linking it to potential deleterious metabolic effects, though more research is needed to confirm these associations.
population_specificity: Developing countries, particularly South Asian and South-East Asian populations, including vegetarians.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of butterbur root extract (Petadolex) for treating asthma in adults and children/adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that butterbur extract reduced the number, duration, and severity of asthma attacks, improved lung function (peak flow and FEV1), and led to over 40% of patients reducing their asthma medication intake. Symptoms improved during therapy, suggesting Petadolex is effective and safe for asthma treatment.
population_specificity: 64 adults and 16 children/adolescents with asthma.
study_duration: Two months of mandatory treatment, followed by two months of optional intake.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the role of contaminated food items, including peanut butter, in causing nontyphoidal salmonellosis.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that peanut butter was implicated in a recent Salmonella outbreak, but it does not provide specific findings about butter's effects.
population_specificity: General population, with risk factors including gastric hypoacidity, recent antibiotic use, extremes of age, and immunosuppressive conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of magnesium supplementation on postprandial lipid responses after consuming butter in healthy subjects.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation reduced and delayed serum and chylomicron TAG responses, and significantly lowered apo-B48, RLP-C, and NEFA concentrations at 2 hours post-consumption compared to butter alone. The study suggested that magnesium could inhibit fat absorption and improve postprandial hyperlipidaemia.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy male volunteers
effective_dosage: 30 g butter with or without 5 ml bittern (containing 500 mg Mg)
study_duration: Single administration with blood samples taken up to 6 hours post-ingestion

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different types of dietary fats, including butter (SFA), affect fatty acid desaturase (FADS) activity indices in human subjects.
results_summary: The study found that a diet containing butter fat (SFA) resulted in a 20% higher SCD-1 activity index compared to a MUFA diet, suggesting butter may influence metabolic markers linked to obesity. D6D and D5D indices remained unaffected by butter consumption.
population_specificity: Healthy human subjects (n=17 in the butter group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of a special butterbur root extract (Petadolex) for migraine prophylaxis in a reanalysis of a randomized, placebo-controlled study.
results_summary: The butterbur group showed a significant reduction in mean migraine frequency (from 3.4 to 1.8 attacks/month) compared to placebo (2.9 to 2.6), with a responder rate of 45% versus 15%. Butterbur was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Patients with migraine (33 in the verum group, 27 in the placebo group).
effective_dosage: Two capsules of 25 mg butterbur twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of a patented special butterbur root extract for migraine prevention in humans.
results_summary: The study concluded that the patented special butterbur root extract is safe for human use, supported by toxicity studies, clinical trials, and postmarketing surveillance. Two placebo-controlled clinical trials indicated beneficial effects for migraine prevention.
population_specificity: Humans (specific population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Butterbur as an add-on therapy to inhaled corticosteroids in atopic asthmatic patients, focusing on anti-inflammatory activity and bronchoprovocation outcomes.
results_summary: Butterbur significantly improved AMP bronchoprovocation response and reduced exhaled nitric oxide, serum eosinophil cationic protein, and peripheral blood eosinophil count compared to placebo, indicating complementary anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Sixteen atopic asthmatic patients maintained on inhaled corticosteroids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Butterbur on objective nasal responsiveness outcomes in patients with seasonal allergic rhinitis during grass pollen season.
results_summary: Butterbur significantly attenuated spontaneous recovery following nasal adenosine monophosphate challenge and blunted the maximum peak nasal inspiratory flow reduction compared to placebo, suggesting protective effects against nasal responsiveness.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with grass-pollen-sensitized seasonal allergic rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing guidelines on the use of nutraceuticals, including Butterbur, for migraine relief and discuss its safety controversy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Butterbur's effects, only noting its inclusion in the review and the ongoing safety controversy.
population_specificity: Adults with migraine (general, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Butterbur as a nonpharmacologic therapy for migraine prevention.
results_summary: The study found that Butterbur, along with other nonpharmacologic therapies, was effective in preventing migraines, showing improvement in migraine symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with migraines, including those with aura.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and tolerability of butterbur with cetirizine in treating seasonal allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Butterbur was similarly effective to cetirizine in improving SF-36 scores and clinical global impression scale scores, with both treatments being well tolerated. Butterbur had fewer sedative side effects compared to cetirizine.
population_specificity: 125 patients with seasonal allergic rhinitis in Switzerland and Germany.
effective_dosage: One tablet (carbon dioxide extract, ZE 339) four times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the wound-healing effects of an anthocyanin complex (AC) derived from purple waxy corn and blue butterfly pea petals, both in free form and encapsulated in niosomes, in vitro and in a clinical trial.
results_summary: AC niosomes accelerated wound healing in fibroblasts and upregulated collagen and extracellular matrix proteins. In a clinical trial, AC niosome gel outperformed AC gel, triamcinolone gel, and placebo in accelerating oral wound closure, reducing pain, and improving quality of life.
population_specificity: 60 volunteers aged 18-60 with oral wounds.
effective_dosage: 0.002 mg/mL (in vitro); gel formulation (clinical trial, exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: 24 hours (in vitro); clinical trial duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anaerobic degradation of caffeine using microbial fuel cells (MFCs) as a sustainable wastewater treatment method under varying operational conditions.
results_summary: The study found that caffeine degradation achieved 100% efficiency within 3-5 days, with higher power generation observed at increased caffeine concentrations. The presence of external nitrogen sources influenced degradation speed, but caffeine itself served as a nitrogen source for anaerobic bacteria.
population_specificity: Synthetic wastewater and anaerobic sludge (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness of caffeine citrate for managing neonatal apnea in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs).
results_summary: Caffeine citrate demonstrated fewer adverse effects (e.g., feeding intolerance, tachycardia) and a lower risk of recurrent apnea compared to aminophylline, establishing its safety, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness for treating prematurity apnea in LMICs.
population_specificity: Preterm infants in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prophylactic caffeine supplementation could mitigate systemic hypercapnia and headache during graded CO2 exposure.
results_summary: Caffeine (400 mg) increased ventilation, lowered end-tidal CO2 levels, and substantially reduced headache severity during CO2 exposure, with the most pronounced effect at 8% inspired CO2.
population_specificity: 24 healthy males and females (23 completed the crossover trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess caffeine's potential as an adjunct medication for reducing opioid consumption in adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) patients following posterior spinal fusion (PSF).
results_summary: Caffeine use resulted in a modest, non-significant reduction in postoperative opioid consumption (5 MME average reduction) compared to placebo, suggesting potential but inconclusive benefits for opioid stewardship. The study was underpowered to definitively assess outcomes.
population_specificity: Adolescents (mean age ~14.5 years, predominantly female) undergoing PSF for AIS.
effective_dosage: Not specified (referred to as "treatment dose" without details).
study_duration: Hospital stay duration (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether caffeine exhibits neuroprotective effects by regulating ACSL4-mediated ferroptosis in neuronal injury caused by hypoxia/reoxygenation.
results_summary: Caffeine improved cell viability, reduced inflammatory cytokines, and inhibited ferroptosis by downregulating ACSL4 and upregulating GPX4. Overexpression of ACSL4 reversed these protective effects, while silencing ACSL4 enhanced them.
population_specificity: HT-22 cells (in vitro neuronal injury model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review clinical trials on the efficacy and safety of topical caffeine preparations for treating hair loss.
results_summary: The review found that topical caffeine was generally effective against hair loss, with all included studies supporting its use, though the quality of evidence varied from medium to very low due to methodological flaws.
population_specificity: 684 individuals with androgenetic alopecia, excessive hair loss, or hair thinning.
effective_dosage: Not specified (lack of information on caffeine concentration in products).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the successful use of caffeine citrate in treating bronchiolitis-related apnea in a specific neonatal case.
results_summary: The study reported a successful use of caffeine citrate for a neonate with bronchiolitis-related apnea, suggesting that certain patient characteristics (e.g., prematurity, absence of respiratory distress) may be key to its effectiveness. However, the evidence remains limited due to the study's case report design.
population_specificity: A neonate with bronchiolitis-related apnea and a background of prematurity, without respiratory distress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of caffeine, alone and in combination with other compounds, against rotenone-induced nigrostriatal neuronal damage in mice.
results_summary: Caffeine, along with Vit E and L-dopa, showed favorable changes in oxidative stress and inflammatory biomarkers, but its combination with citicholine was not superior to citicholine alone at higher doses.
population_specificity: Swiss male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize population pharmacokinetic studies of caffeine in preterm infants and identify covariates influencing its pharmacokinetic parameters.
results_summary: The study found that caffeine pharmacokinetics in preterm infants mostly followed a one-compartment model, with covariates like birth weight, genetic polymorphism, and feeding patterns affecting PK parameters. It emphasized the need for individualized dosing regimens for safe and effective treatment.
population_specificity: Preterm infants
interactions: Combination medications and feeding patterns were noted as influencing factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability and compatibility of caffeine in TrichoSol™ as a compounding vehicle for alopecia therapies.
results_summary: The study found that caffeine remains stable in TrichoSol™ for 180 days at room temperature, supporting its use in compounded topical formulations for hair loss treatment. No efficacy data on hair growth outcomes were provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on formulation stability, not human subjects).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the influence of clinically relevant inotropic agents (dobutamine, epinephrine, and milrinone) on mucociliary clearance, not Caffeine.
results_summary: The study found that dobutamine, epinephrine, and milrinone increased particle transport velocity (PTV) in a dose-dependent manner, mediated by intracellular calcium release and specific signaling pathways (PKA and PLC). Caffeine was not studied.
population_specificity: Isolated murine tracheae (mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize caffeine pharmacokinetics in term infants with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) receiving cooling and evaluate potential neuroprotective dosing strategies.
results_summary: The study found that current dosing regimens (20 mg/kg followed by 5 mg/kg) resulted in suboptimal plasma exposures, while higher doses (30 mg/kg followed by 5 or 10 mg/kg) improved target range attainment without significant toxicity. Term infants with HIE had similar clearance but higher volume of distribution compared to preterm infants without HIE.
population_specificity: Term infants with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) receiving cooling therapy.
effective_dosage: Initial IV dose of 20 mg/kg, followed by up to two daily doses of 5 or 10 mg/kg.
study_duration: Short-term (exact duration not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects of caffeine on metabolic-associated steatohepatitis (MASH) and identify its underlying mechanisms, particularly focusing on hepatic steatosis, inflammation, and fibrosis.
results_summary: Caffeine reduced hepatic steatosis, inflammation, and early-stage liver fibrosis in MASH mice by restoring Dusp9 expression and inactivating the ASK1-p38/JNK pathway, thereby improving glycolipid metabolism disorders.
population_specificity: MASH mice induced by prolonged high-fat high-carbohydrate (HFHC) diets and high-fat diets combined with carbon tetrachloride (CCl4) injections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of intravenous caffeine citrate in treating pediatric asthma exacerbations unresponsive to beta2-agonists and steroids.
results_summary: Caffeine citrate and magnesium sulphate showed comparable effectiveness in improving PRAM scores, duration of oxygen therapy, and PICU stay, with no serious adverse events in the caffeine group. The differences between the two treatments were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Asthmatic children (median ages 2.3 and 3.0 years) unresponsive to beta2-agonists and steroids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the incidence of acute kidney injury (AKI) in very-low-birth-weight preterm infants treated with early high-dose caffeine and identify associated risk factors.
results_summary: The study found a 14% incidence of AKI in infants treated with caffeine, with only 4% occurring in the first week. Infants with AKI had worse outcomes, including higher mortality and longer hospitalization.
population_specificity: Very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) preterm infants (< 1500 g) born at < 32 weeks of gestation.
effective_dosage: 20 mg/kg bolus in the first hour of life, followed by 10 mg/kg/day maintenance.
study_duration: Not specified (retrospective cohort study covering admissions from 2017-2019).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether combining caffeine intake with listening to music during warm-up enhances anaerobic performance compared to music alone or no intervention.
results_summary: Combining caffeine (3 mg/kg) with music significantly improved peak power, mean power, and total work in the Wingate anaerobic test compared to music alone or control. Peak power was higher with caffeine plus music than with music alone, and self-perceived power also increased.
population_specificity: 24 physically active male participants.
effective_dosage: 3 mg/kg of caffeine, taken 60 minutes before exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic interactions between caffeine and five main classes of antidepressants.
results_summary: Caffeine showed varying effects on different antidepressant classes, including increased concentrations of some antidepressants (e.g., fluvoxamine, paroxetine) and altered renal clearance (e.g., fluoxetine, escitalopram). Minimal interactions were noted with venlafaxine, while MAOIs combined with caffeine increased hypertension risk.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on antidepressant users).
interactions: Significant interactions noted with SSRIs, TCAs, MAOIs, and miscellaneous antidepressants; minimal interaction with SNRIs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the performance of 3D-printed electrochemical sensors for detecting caffeine (CAF) and paracetamol (PAR) simultaneously.
results_summary: The study found that treated and activated 3D-printed sensors achieved limits of detection of 0.58 μmol L-1 for caffeine, demonstrating effective electrochemical analysis. The sequential physical, chemical, and electrochemical treatments significantly enhanced sensor performance.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using electrochemical sensors).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (sensor detection limit: 0.58 μmol L-1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy, safety, and long-term developmental effects of low-dose (5mg/kg) versus high-dose (10mg/kg) caffeine citrate in treating primary apnea of prematurity (AOP).
results_summary: High-dose caffeine citrate reduced incidences of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) and periventricular leukomalacia (PVL), improved long-term motor and mental development scores at 12 months, and showed no significant difference in hospitalization costs compared to low-dose treatment. Short-term efficacy metrics (apnea events, ventilation duration) were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (n=146) with primary apnea of prematurity (AOP).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (retrospective study spanning December 2019–December 2023).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether topical caffeine, alone or combined with atropine, could slow myopia progression in children.
results_summary: Topical 2% caffeine alone did not slow myopia progression. When combined with atropine, caffeine did not enhance atropine's efficacy in slowing myopia.
population_specificity: 96 children aged 6-13 with myopia (spherical equivalent -0.50D to -6.00D, astigmatism <2.00D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of caffeine on cardiac health in rats with experimentally induced hypothyroidism.
results_summary: Caffeine administration alongside or after PTU treatment in hypothyroid rats appeared to ameliorate thyroid and cardiac irregularities, including reducing hyperemia, microhemorrhages, and maintaining cardiac troponin expression.
population_specificity: Rats induced with hypothyroidism using propylthiouracil (PTU).
